references: Black, J.H. 1974. Notes on Plethodon ouachitae in Oklahoma. Proceedings of the Oklahoma Academy of Science 54:88-89.
Black, J.H. and W.L. Puckette. 1974. The Ouachia salamander in Oklahoma caves. Proceedings of the Oklahoma Underground 6:42-44.

Anthony, C.D. 2005. Plethodon ouachitae (Dunn and Heinze 1933), Rich Mountain Salamander. In Lannoo (Ed.), Amphibian Declines. The Conservation Status of United States Species, University of California Press, Berkeley, CA. p. 831-833.
Wilson, L. A. 1995. The Land Manager's Guide to the amphibians and reptiles of the South. Chapel Hill, NC: The Nature Conservancy.
IUCN. 2014. The IUCN Red List of Threatened Species. Version 2014.1. http://www.iucnredlist.org. Downloaded March 2016.
habitat_description: Plethodon ouachitae are locally distributed in the Ouachita Mountains of eastern Oklahoma and western Arkansas (Anthony 2005). In Arkansas, the current distribution includes parts of Rich, Fourche, and Blackfork mountains where hybridization is occurring with P. fourchensis (Anthony 2005). They can be found at higher elevations on north-facing slopes adjacent to seeps where they seek cover under sandstone rocks, logs, and other forest (Black 1974, Anthony 2005). Cave entrances are utilized on occasion (Black 1974, Black and Puckette 1974). Occupied mesic forested habitats tend to be along cooler and wetter ridges, slopes, and ravines (Wilson 1995).
